abstracts.cdata!:
The First, Second, and Third Performance
            and Accountability of Social Sectors Development Policy
            Loans for Dominican Republic had a satisfactory outcome with
            the moderate risk to development outcome and satisfactory
            performances by both the bank and borrower. The lessons
            learned include: (1) the programmatic development policy
            approach proved to be a suitable instrument for this
            intervention. (2) The process for transforming a system of
            subsidy transfers into a proper CCT is complex and it needs
            careful design and planning. (3) Implementation of an
            M&E system, covering a decentralized system of service
            providers, is very complex, takes time, and needs a strong
            managerial leadership. (4) Reducing the number of policy
            actions agreed in each operation was useful to have a more
            manageable program. (5) Having a multi-sectorial team was
            critical to achieving synergies; working across sectors can
            reinforce results. (6) A real programmatic approach that
            builds on complementarities with other Bank simultaneous
            interventions was highly helpful. (7) A combination of an
            impending crisis, relevant analytical work, and political
            leadership provided strong entry points to define an
            ambitious reform agenda. (8) The extra effort demanded by
            the implementation of a complex DPL program was more than
            compensated by achieving a wide range of reforms in a short
            period of time.
